text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with garlic parmesan dinner rolls
so you know what the problem with this
recipe is it actually looks too awesome
i know it doesn't sound like a big
problem and i'll explain later but for
now let me show you how to start this
surprisingly simple and really delicious
dinner roll so here we go into a mixing
bowl we're gonna add some yeast some
flour and some warm water and basically
what we're making here is kind of a thin
sponge and all sponges is just giving
the yeast a little head start so it gets
a nice chance to start growing before
the rest of the ingredients are
introduced and i almost forgot i like to
put a little bit of sugar into the
sponge yeast likes to eat sugar
who doesn't all right I'm gonna stir
that in I'm going to cover this I just
happen to have a piece of foil handy you
could use a towel of course and I'm
gonna put that in a warm spot you know
seventy seventy-five degrees something
like that I'm gonna set that in warm
spot for about 15-20 minutes after which
it's gonna look like this have I
mentioned lately that making bread is
super fun so if you've never done it
well why not
come on all right at that point into the
sponge we're gonna add some salt some
olive oil and believe it or not an egg
and that egg is just going to add a
little bit of richness alright so I'm
going to mix that in thoroughly and then
oh yeah we need some flour and yes this
is a no need dough which should be great
news for you non eaters so I'm going to
dump in my flour I'm going to use my
rounded wooden spoon and I'm going to go
ahead and I'm going to stir that flour
in and it may be enough it may not be
enough I want you to stir and stir and
stir and there should be enough flour in
there where you're gonna form a very
very sticky lump of dough it should just
barely pull away from the sides like
that so just keep stirring and stirring
and only add enough flour if it won't
pull away from the sides and then you're
fine for the next step which is the
rising so what I'm going to do here is
I'm going to cover this with a damp a
towel so this is going to go back in
that proverbial warm spot for about an
hour to an hour and a half until it
basically doubles in size or more so for
me an hour and 15 minutes later this is
what it looked like so gorgeous so
beautiful just so supple and filled with
gas alright we're going to take a big
spatula and just knock all the air out
of this just scrape down the sides and
what you're going to do is you're going
to scrape this right onto a well floured
work surface generously flour your
cutting board scrape the dough down and
then generously flour the top of the
dough and then with your fingers you're
just going to kind of Pat it down and
stretch it into a very rough rectangular
shape something like that alright once
I've accomplished that I'm going to take
a rolling pin and continue rolling this
a little thinner I want it to be about a
half inch thick and again I want to keep
it into a general rectangular shape so
once our dough is rolled out we're going
to go ahead and add the fillings which
are as the title gave away garlic and
Parmesan mostly so I'm going to take a
crushed garlic clove or two up to you
and you can just put that right on the
dough straight although I like to mix it
in a little bit of butter or olive oil
or both and then spread it on and you're
probably thinking that looks like more
than one or two garlic cloves it might
have been a little more but like I said
you use how much you want all right
after the garlic spread edge we are
going to the cheese sprinkle edge which
is going to be real Reggiano parmesan
please do not use the fake cheese I say
that every time but it really is a
tremendous difference all right after
the cheese I'm going to put a little bit
of seasoning you're not going to need
any salt but I'm going to do a little
black pepper a little bit of paprika and
or cayenne I'm not going to confirm or
deny I use cayenne and last but not
least a generous sprinkling of freshly
chopped Italian parsley and that's it
for the filling next I'm going to take
one figure and I'm going to go down the
edge pressing down pressing down like
that that's going to help us seal this
when we roll it now it's probably sticky
enough to seal anyway but I'm going to
paint a little bit of water on it just
to be sure I just barely damp you don't
want it wet and then from the opposite
end I want you to slowly start rolling
just like you're rolling a big old
burrito not too tight we don't want any
big air pockets in the middle but we
don't want to smoosh everything either
all right so once that's rolled up we
want to end up with the seam at the
bottom that just makes sense and then
we're going to cut it in half and then
each half into four now I do like to
trim off the last half inch or so
because that's pretty much all dough so
I do that and then like I said each half
gets cut into four pieces so
my math is correct this is going to give
you eight dinner rolls altogether and
we're going to place those on a lined
baking sheet cut side up all right next
you're going to take scissors and you're
going to make a nice deep cut into the
top of each one of these some might
already be open but it doesn't matter I
don't want them a little open I want a
giant gaping gash so after we cut the
center's like that we're going to go
ahead and paint a little bit more oil or
butter on the top now I had enough in my
little container where I had my minced
garlic to brush these if you don't just
a few drops of oil on your pastry brush
will be fine all right after those are
lightly lubricated we're going to go
ahead and sprinkle some more parmesan on
top a couple teaspoons on each and then
before these are baked we have to proof
them which means give them a little pre
baking rise so they're going to go back
into my oven again not on just the
lights on and those are going to sit
there for twenty to thirty minutes after
which they're going to look like this
kind of puffy those are ready to bake so
you're going to pre-heat your oven to
400 degrees and you're going to bake
these for about 20 minutes and I promise
you after 20 minutes you're going to be
looking at some pretty gorgeous rolls
all right as soon as they come out of
the oven you know I like to get these on
a rack to cool and that is it are those
gorgeous or what and that's the problem
as I mentioned at the beginning of the
video these look so amazing that people
think they're going to be more than what
they are which is just a nice dinner
roll when you pull back that napkin in
the breadbasket and these beauties are
revealed try to manage expectations all
right anyway other than that they're
fantastic now to be completely honest
and I always end with you people
I cooked mine for 25 minutes and they
were a little dry in fact some of you as
stewed bankers as I break this open you
can see that grain is just a hair on the
dry side so 25 minutes was a little too
long so check yours of 20 minutes that
should be fine anyway yes there's a few
steps but none of them are hard so I
hope you give that a try head over to
food wishes comm for all the ingredient
amounts and more information as usual
and as always enjoy
